edu.vserver.exercises.model
Interface ResourceGiver

All Superinterfaces:
java.io.Serializable
All Known Implementing Classes:
StubResourceGiverImpl
public interface ResourceGiver
extends java.io.Serializable

Implementors of this class provide localization and certain resourcse to the current session.

To use the getUIText(String) you must define a ViLLE-specific language file (.trl) and add it to the used language-files directory.

When using stub-ViLLE the language file directory is defined in the class implementing AbstractExerStubUI and used as (main)-UI for the vaadin session. The language file directory is in "ville-stub-base"/lang .

ViLLE-language file-format (eg. example.trl): 

 // for comment (must start line)
 @key:KEY_CONSTANT
 @en:english translation
 @fi:finnish translation
 
 etc...
 
 @key:another key constant
 
 etc...
Empty lines are allowed and will be ignored. Any constant or translation can span multiple lines; explicit line breaks \n etc must be added explicitly. Every comment line must start with "//"; this is the only supported comment-syntax. The defined translation tags must be of format @'some valid ISO Language Code'. (see Locale)

The file name of a .trl-file will be added implicitly in upper-case to all keys defined in a file to avoid conflicts between keys defined in different loaded .trl-files. To get a translation defined in the aforementioned file you can call getUIText(String) with eg. "EXAMPLE.KEY_CONSTANT" or "EXAMPLE.another key constant".

It is possible to reference the translations directly with Strings eg. "EXAMPLE.KEY_CONSTANT" but it is generally advisable to collect the keys to a constants file to avoid typos and to allow automatic testing.

The translations can also contain parameters. (For more info see getUIText(key, params...).) Example: 

 @key:KEY_WITH_PARAMS
 @en:@0 is equal to @0 but not necessarily to @1
 
 getUIText("EXAMPLE.KEY_WITH_PARAMS", "" + 1, "" + 3)
 would return:
 1 is equal to 1 but not necessarily to 3

Author:
Riku Haavisto, Johannes Holvitie

Method Detail

getUIText

java.lang.String getUIText(java.lang.String key)

Return a chunk of UI text, usually a single caption or a label, in currently selected language.

If translation in current language (as defined by getCurrentLocale()'s #getLanguage() getLanguage() ) is not found translation in #ENGLISH is returned. If translation in #ENGLISH is not found the key-parameter is returned as such.

Parameters:
key - the key of the UI text to be returned
Returns:
the UI text for given key.

getUIText

java.lang.String getUIText(java.lang.String key,
                           java.lang.String... params)

Return a chunk of UI text, usually a single caption or a label, in currently selected language..
The parameters given are inserted into UI text, replacing all the @0...@n tags, where n is the index of last parameter.

If translation in current language is not found to situation is handled similarly as in getUIText(String). If the returned translation does not contain the needed @i-tags no error is raised but the i'th param is simply ignored.

Parameters:
key - the key of the UI text to be returned
params - the parameters inserted in this UI text in correct order.
Returns:
the UI text for given key with parameters inserted.

getCurrentLocale

java.util.Locale getCurrentLocale()

Locale used in the current user session can be used for localization of for example dates (eg. #getDateInstance(int, Locale).

The getUIText(String) and related mechanisms should be used for UI-text translations.

Returns:
the locale used in the current user session

getTestingExerciseView

Component getTestingExerciseView(Executor<?,?> toTest,
                                 GeneralExerciseInfo exerInfo)
Returns a Component containing all the needed controls for controlling the given Executor. The main use case for this method is to provide a testing view from Editor. The caller must itself know which GeneralExerciseExecutor to instantiate and how to load it with data.
